quotes.topic_title: Opening: Talent density as culture foundation
quotes.text: We can't really have any of the other aspects of the culture, including candor, learning, seeking excellence in improvement, freedom and responsibility if you don't start with high talent density.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Positions talent density as the foundational prerequisite that enables other cultural values to function in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Opening: Talent density as culture foundation
quotes.text: So when he founded Netflix and grew the company over time, it was with a belief that there could be a different approach to building a company that would make it a place that people thrived in and loved being and would feel different than other places, both in the quality of that talent density, but even more importantly, the excellence and the outcomes.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Highlights an outcomes-first culture design: talent density matters, but it’s ultimately in service of excellence and results.

quotes.topic_title: Opening: Talent density as culture foundation
quotes.text: And in order to do that, you have to really hold yourself to a lot of stuff that doesn't feel like natural human behavior.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that sustaining a high-performance culture requires deliberate discipline beyond default human tendencies.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Elizabeth is chief technology officer at Netflix, and as far as I can tell, the first economist to ever be named CTO at a Fortune 500 company.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific, memorable data point that frames an unconventional path into top tech leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We talk about how an economics background has helped Elizabeth in her career and why she expects to see more economists rise in the ranks of tech companies.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a contrarian career thesis: economics training can be a differentiator for tech leadership progression.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: She shares some of her secret sauce for rising so quickly at so many companies so consistently.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals practical career-acceleration tactics that practitioners can look to extract and apply.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We delve into Netflix's very unique culture of high talent density, radical candor, and freedom and responsibility.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Names a concrete cultural framework that can be used as a lens for designing teams and operating norms.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We also talk about the structure that Netflix has for their data and user research teams, which she believes is a part of Netflix's secret to success.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to org design (data + research structure) as a repeatable lever for product and company performance.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Now you can assess risk, secure the trust of your customers, and automate compliance for SOC 2, ISO 27001, HIPAA and more with a single platform, Vanta.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Highlights a consolidated approach to risk, trust, and compliance automation across multiple standards.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta's market leading trust management platform helps you continuously monitor compliance alongside reporting and tracking risks.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Emphasizes continuous compliance monitoring paired with risk reporting as an operational model.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Plus, you can save hours by completing security questionnaires with Vanta AI.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Actionable example of using AI to reduce time spent on repetitive security review work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In a world saturated with multi-channel communication, product teams are discovering the effectiveness of in-app communication.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sendbird)
quotes.context: Frames a shift in channel strategy toward in-app communication as a more effective focus area.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In-app communication has the highest conversion, highest engagement, and highest satisfaction of any communication channel.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sendbird)
quotes.context: A strong comparative claim that can guide prioritization of communication channels for product teams.

quotes.topic_title: CTO transition: context switching and stakes
quotes.text: I would say the biggest thing that changed is probably the amount of context switching and the degree to which I feel behind or I have a lot to learn.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Highlights a practical expectation-setting model for senior leadership roles: the job shift is largely about rapid context switching and continuous learning.

quotes.topic_title: CTO transition: context switching and stakes
quotes.text: but the engineering organization just takes that to 100 basically.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A memorable way to convey how scope and complexity can scale nonlinearly when moving into org-wide technical leadership.

quotes.topic_title: CTO transition: context switching and stakes
quotes.text: So more people to get to know, more problem spaces, aspects of technical expertise that I'm just not as deeply familiar with.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that succeeding as CTO requires building relationships and navigating many domains, not just going deeper in one specialty.

quotes.topic_title: CTO transition: context switching and stakes
quotes.text: Yes. So thankfully not a lot of meetings that Netflix feel like now you're really in this scary room, but it does feel like the role has more consequence, which is actually an exciting thing.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframing: higher-stakes decisions don’t have to feel intimidating—more consequence can be motivating and energizing.

quotes.topic_title: Economics background as a tech advantage
quotes.text: Yes to the last question. That's the easiest of it.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A direct, unambiguous recommendation that tech companies should hire more economists.

quotes.topic_title: Economics background as a tech advantage
quotes.text: economics is a flavor of data science.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that positions economics as a practical, technical toolkit relevant to modern data-driven work.

quotes.topic_title: Economics background as a tech advantage
quotes.text: So it is a set of technical skills for sure. It's a way of framing certain problems or solving challenges.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Highlights economics as both skills and a problem-framing methodology practitioners can apply beyond traditional econ roles.

quotes.topic_title: Economics background as a tech advantage
quotes.text: I think that economics is generally valuable for a lot of different challenges and it's a useful perspective to add to things, especially in a business context and especially in how we want to simplify problems in a way that makes them feel tractable.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A concrete mental model: use economic thinking to simplify complex business problems into tractable ones.

quotes.topic_title: Economics background as a tech advantage
quotes.text: I don't know that many people at Netflix think of me as an economist, but I find it comes out in the way I think about things.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A practical reminder that domain training can be most valuable as an implicit thinking style, not a job title.

quotes.topic_title: Incentives and unintended consequences thinking
quotes.text: So one example would probably be in an understanding incentives and thinking about unintended consequences.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A practical mental model: evaluate decisions by mapping incentives and anticipating second-order effects.

quotes.topic_title: Incentives and unintended consequences thinking
quotes.text: I think that that is true both in terms of internal leadership, so being part of a management team that's thinking about how do we clarify priorities or motivate a company or define the problems we want to solve. And then part of it is more externally oriented. How do we want to think about what Netflix is to consumers and how we want to think about competition?
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Applies the same incentives lens to both internal management decisions and external market positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Incentives and unintended consequences thinking
quotes.text: There can be a rational way of thought, which is one version of economics of shouldn't rational intelligent people behave in the following way. And then there's the, well, if given certain incentives, what might you see that we didn't think was optimal or we weren't expecting to happen but could be a consequence or repercussion here?
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A two-mode decision check: contrast idealized rational behavior with incentive-driven behavior to surface unintended consequences.

quotes.topic_title: Incentives and unintended consequences thinking
quotes.text: And so I think that that type of framing, I don't know if it's unique to economics in a way because it has elements of psychology to it as well and planning ahead has become really useful for thinking through cause and effect.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Highlights a cross-disciplinary approach—economics plus psychology—to plan ahead and reason about cause-and-effect.

quotes.topic_title: Incentives and unintended consequences thinking
quotes.text: So at your first job, you went from associate to vice president in three years. At the next company, Nuna, you went from manager of data science to COO in two years. At Netflix you went from VP to CTO in three years.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete career progression data points that set up a discussion on what drives outsized growth and impact.

quotes.topic_title: Secret sauce behind rapid career progression
quotes.text: It's been part who I am for a long time that I give everything I've got to the job that I'm in.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable principle—full commitment to the current role—as a driver of rapid progression.

quotes.topic_title: Secret sauce behind rapid career progression
quotes.text: I do the best work I possibly can, less so for myself and my own ambition and more so because I think of myself as being part of a team and so I really need to deliver for that team.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Offers a team-first motivation model that reframes excellence as responsibility to others rather than personal ambition.

quotes.topic_title: Secret sauce behind rapid career progression
quotes.text: I have found that part of that is being someone that people can leverage to translate from technical to non-technical and non-technical to technical.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Identifies cross-functional “translation” as a practical, high-leverage skill that accelerates impact and advancement.

quotes.topic_title: Secret sauce behind rapid career progression
quotes.text: I'm a relatively introverted only child, so I observe a lot, which means that I learned from other people.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A counterintuitive take that introversion can be an advantage by enabling deliberate observation-based learning.

quotes.topic_title: Secret sauce behind rapid career progression
quotes.text: And in each of these roles I have tried really hard to watch what other people are doing, think about how could I learn something from them, whether it's the thing that I want to be able to do myself or it's the thing that I think, "Oh, that doesn't quite fit or feel authentic with my style."
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Provides an actionable learning methodology: observe others and decide what to adopt vs. what to reject as inauthentic.

quotes.topic_title: High standards without burnout; live content example
quotes.text: No, and it's a good clarification because the dedication piece really isn't about long working hours. It's more about how much I care about excellence, I guess.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Reframes “dedication” away from hours worked toward a standards-and-excellence mindset that avoids burnout culture.

quotes.topic_title: High standards without burnout; live content example
quotes.text: So whether it's the timing for a meeting or providing input on something or reviewing a document or following through on something I said that I was going to do, and I really try to avoid that, which means that if someone sends me something, I try to be very responsive about it. If I know that I said I'm going to do something, I follow through on it in the timeline that I said I was going to do. If I have a meeting, I try to be on time to that meeting.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, repeatable “reliability” playbook (responsiveness, follow-through, punctuality) as the operational definition of high standards.

quotes.topic_title: High standards without burnout; live content example
quotes.text: A big part of my role is, can I explain how we're going to approach those technical problems in a way that builds competence with the content team? Can I try to understand their content strategy in a way that sets the technical teams up for success and we understand what we need to be able to deliver on here in terms of requirements.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Describes a translation framework for cross-functional work: build partner competence while converting strategy into clear technical requirements.

quotes.topic_title: High standards without burnout; live content example
quotes.text: Well, yeah, that was about a little less than a year ago now. So the amazing thing about failure is you learn a lot. We learned a lot. We've taken notes on it and we had a couple successful events after that, including the Netflix Cup last October.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Uses the Love Is Blind live failure as a learning loop example—capture lessons (“taken notes”) and apply them to subsequent successful launches.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching excellence: expectations, feedback, and help
quotes.text: It shows up for the people who report to me, is one part example setting. So if I don't do it, why would they do it? I treat that very seriously that we should all be held to the same standards.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Sets a clear leadership model: raising the bar starts with visibly holding yourself to the same standard you expect from others.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching excellence: expectations, feedback, and help
quotes.text: And as a second thing, I give feedback when it's not up to the standard. So I think one of the things I've observed especially with people on my teams is that the expectations aren't always clear and you can't assume that they're clear if you don't share them. When something's not meeting expectations or really showing up as excellence, I think it's a combination of both giving the feedback on that and being direct about it and being specific about what would it take to get this to the bar that I am expecting or to show up in the way that I'm expecting.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A practical coaching method: make expectations explicit, then deliver direct, specific feedback tied to what “good” concretely looks like.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching excellence: expectations, feedback, and help
quotes.text: And then the third and probably most important thing is help them fill that gap.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Completes a simple, actionable framework: excellence isn’t just critique—leaders actively help close the delta to the bar.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching excellence: expectations, feedback, and help
quotes.text: I can both give the feedback on that to make sure like, yes, it's going to take another round of iteration, yes, we're going to have to work another week on this and not be done with it, but pushing people to get there, and then jumping into the document and helping.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Concrete example of “helping fill the gap”: insist on another iteration cycle and then co-work to raise quality rather than just demanding it.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching excellence: expectations, feedback, and help
quotes.text: I do often do that behind the scenes. So maybe that's another flavor of this, which is, I don't do it live in the big meeting in front of all the people where the presentation doesn't go very well. I do it afterwards where it feels like a safer space to say, "Here's a way this could have gone better. Let's think about this differently next time."
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Counterintuitive feedback tactic: preserve psychological safety by delivering critical coaching privately after the moment, not publicly in real time.

quotes.topic_title: Excellence vs polish: focus on outcomes
quotes.text: If we're clear on the objectives of something, it might be that the last 20% of polish on the document is a really bad use of time.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for avoiding burnout by cutting low-ROI “final polish” work when objectives are already clear.

quotes.topic_title: Excellence vs polish: focus on outcomes
quotes.text: The reason we're doing the quarterly business review is to have a really candid conversation about how we think things are going, to have a debate about things where maybe we're stuck. It's not to have a perfectly polished document for that conversation.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Reframes QBRs from a deliverable-driven exercise to an outcome-driven forum for candor and debate.

quotes.topic_title: Excellence vs polish: focus on outcomes
quotes.text: So my feedback in that instance would be, I would much rather have someone spend the time thinking about what's the conversation we really want to have? "How do I tee that up?" Not, "Could I spend another 20 hours to make it look like everything's perfect in this document?"
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A concrete tradeoff: invest effort in shaping the discussion and decisions, not in making artifacts look flawless.

quotes.topic_title: Excellence vs polish: focus on outcomes
quotes.text: This is expectation setting.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Clarifies that preventing wasted effort starts upstream by setting expectations before work is done.

quotes.topic_title: Excellence vs polish: focus on outcomes
quotes.text: Oh wait, if you're on the last 20% of this polishing the dock, I'd rather spend time over here.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A memorable way to redirect teams from diminishing-returns polish to higher-impact work.

quotes.topic_title: Netflix culture: talent density and keeper test
quotes.text: But a lot of it is, we can't really have any of the other aspects of the culture, including candor, learning, seeking excellence and improvement, freedom and responsibility if you don't start with high talent density.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Frames talent density as the prerequisite that enables the rest of the culture to function, not just a hiring goal.

quotes.topic_title: Netflix culture: talent density and keeper test
quotes.text: And so in some ways it's not the end, it's the means to the end in what Reed and the rest of the leadership team has been trying to build.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Counterintuitively positions “high talent density” as an enabling mechanism rather than the ultimate objective.

quotes.topic_title: Netflix culture: talent density and keeper test
quotes.text: Where if I'm asking myself the question, "If this person on my team came to me and said, 'I'm leaving today. I have a different opportunity and I would like to take it,' would I do everything I could to keep them at Netflix?" If not, then I should be having that tough conversation about, "Should you really be here? Are you in the right role?", if I might be a little bit relieved if you said you were leaving.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Defines the keeper test as a concrete decision-making heuristic for retention and role-fit conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Netflix culture: talent density and keeper test
quotes.text: So we don't have a practice that a lot of other companies do where we would think about reflecting on a rating of how things are going.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Challenges the default assumption that formal ratings/performance reviews are necessary to manage performance.

quotes.topic_title: Netflix culture: talent density and keeper test
quotes.text: It's like you have to keep reminding yourself, "This is our ideal" because it's really easy to rely on the annual 360 cycle.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Highlights an operational pitfall: even with a feedback culture, teams can backslide into periodic processes unless they deliberately reinforce real-time feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Reducing fear: clarity through frequent feedback
quotes.text: In my personal experience, I have felt a lot more at ease by having these conversations than by not having them.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Reframes frequent performance conversations as a stress-reducer rather than a stressor in high-expectation cultures.

quotes.topic_title: Reducing fear: clarity through frequent feedback
quotes.text: And that made me feel much more stressed or nervous or at risk than having it be part of the culture to have those conversations.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Highlights ambiguity (not feedback) as the real driver of anxiety, implying a cultural practice of explicit feedback lowers fear.

quotes.topic_title: Reducing fear: clarity through frequent feedback
quotes.text: And that's where I think it's helpful to know we expect to have these conversations so you can just kind of let your shoulders relax a little bit of, "Yes, the expectations are high, but my manager says I'm doing a great job, or my manager says I'm not doing a great job, but they gave me concrete things that I could do better."
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Offers a practical mechanism—normalize explicit, concrete feedback—to reduce fear while maintaining a high bar.

quotes.topic_title: Reducing fear: clarity through frequent feedback
quotes.text: And so I think knowing is better than not.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A concise mental model: clarity beats uncertainty, especially in performance management.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for bar-raising, not box-checking
quotes.text: Yeah, I mean on the compensation point, we pay what we call personal top of market, meaning we want to be highly competitive in the pay, but we don't want pay to be like the golden handcuffs of Netflix sets market rather than paying people a strongly competitive compensation.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Defines Netflix’s compensation philosophy (“personal top of market”) and rejects using pay as retention handcuffs.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for bar-raising, not box-checking
quotes.text: The way that I've thought about hiring with that context is we know we're going to offer you very highly competitive compensation, but are you going to come to Netflix and help us identify the right problems to solve or new ways to solve existing problems?
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Reframes hiring from skill matching to assessing problem-finding and novel solution capability.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for bar-raising, not box-checking
quotes.text: But at Netflix we try really hard to say we're looking for the new perspective or the person who's actually going to make us stronger as a team. So thinking about additive skills, additive perspectives, people who are going to push our thinking on something.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Introduces an “additive” hiring lens—optimize for candidates who uplevel the team’s thinking, not just fit a role.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for bar-raising, not box-checking
quotes.text: So then the questions you have to ask in an interview might be different because yes, we're trying to assess do you have the baseline skills to be successful here, but we're also looking for the things that make people exceptional or even stronger than the team we've got.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Actionable interviewing guidance: evaluate baseline competence plus bar-raising traits relative to the current team.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for bar-raising, not box-checking
quotes.text: And I think understanding that having gaps in the team and people's skillsets or their behavior can be really toxic for other people on the team. So it's a cost.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Highlights the hidden organizational cost of tolerating skill/behavior gaps—team toxicity and drag on performance.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Building analytics from scratch can be time-consuming, expensive, and a really challenging process.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the core build-vs-buy tradeoff and why teams should consider alternatives to custom-building analytics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Xplo is a fully white labeled embedded analytics solution designed entirely with your user in mind.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concise product positioning statement that frames embedded analytics as a user-centric, brand-consistent capability.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And with its low-code functionality, you can build and style dashboards in minutes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete claim about speed-to-ship that suggests a practical way to reduce engineering time spent on analytics UI.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Once you're ready, simply embed the dashboard or report into your application with a tiny code snippet.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Describes an implementation approach (embed via snippet) that lowers integration friction for product teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The best part? Your end users can use Xplo's AI features for their own report and dashboard generation, eliminating customer data requests for your support team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive support-scaling idea: shift reporting creation to end users to reduce inbound data requests.

quotes.topic_title: Freedom and responsibility: what others shouldn’t copy
quotes.text: talent density is a prerequisite for a lot of the other ways we operate.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A clear prerequisite framing: Netflix’s cultural practices depend on having unusually high talent density first.

quotes.topic_title: Freedom and responsibility: what others shouldn’t copy
quotes.text: I think that that would be very hard if not dangerous if we didn't have a high talent density.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that copying “freedom” without the same talent bar can create real risk.

quotes.topic_title: Freedom and responsibility: what others shouldn’t copy
quotes.text: It's really not a top down do A, then B, then C.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A memorable description of bottom-up contribution as an operating model rather than leader-driven sequencing.

quotes.topic_title: Freedom and responsibility: what others shouldn’t copy
quotes.text: So I think the lack of process and prescriptiveness is all hinging on we've got amazing people who are smart, but even better have strong judgment.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: Actionable hiring/selection guidance: judgment (not just intelligence) is what makes low-process environments work.

quotes.topic_title: Freedom and responsibility: what others shouldn’t copy
quotes.text: They were driven in many cases by individual contributors who had great ideas for innovation.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A concrete example of how autonomy translates into innovation originating from ICs rather than leadership mandates.

quotes.topic_title: Candor in practice: transparency and IC levels change
quotes.text: It's part of the culture to context, not control, which means part of my job is to make sure that people have the context they need to do their jobs well.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A clear leadership framework that operationalizes transparency as enabling autonomy rather than enforcing compliance.

quotes.topic_title: Candor in practice: transparency and IC levels change
quotes.text: And in practice, that means I take notes in leadership meetings and I share those notes with the whole organization.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable mechanism for scaling candor and alignment: publish leadership-meeting notes broadly.

quotes.topic_title: Candor in practice: transparency and IC levels change
quotes.text: until two years ago, individual contributors didn't have levels at Netflix. So all engineers were just senior engineers, all data scientists were senior data scientists, and we did not have a leveling system.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A specific, surprising data point about Netflix’s historical approach to leveling that sets up the tradeoffs of adding structure at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Candor in practice: transparency and IC levels change
quotes.text: But when you get to a scale of an organization, we needed some type of scaffolding to say, "We want to talk about how we compose teams. When do we need the person who has 30 years of experience? When do we want to have a new grad?" Because that's what the work requires. We didn't have a language for it.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A practical rationale for introducing levels: create shared language for team composition based on work needs, not bureaucracy.

quotes.topic_title: Candor in practice: transparency and IC levels change
quotes.text: And I would rather share that information than pretend it's all gone swimmingly and we achieved every objective.
quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.context: A contrarian stance on change management: do a candid retro after the change to surface what didn’t work instead of moving on.
